node.title: Cryptocurrency hacks growing costlier to investors
node.description: Hackers target so-called DeFi platforms because their security measures are often weak, experts say.

node.title: Coach who lost his job for praying on the field brings case to Supreme Court
node.description: The justices will hear arguments in the religious liberty case on Monday.

node.title: Blinken and Austin sneak into Ukraine's capital to meet with Zelenskyy
node.description: America's top diplomat said Russia was failing and "Ukraine is succeeding," and the Pentagon chief said success would include a "weakened" Russia.

node.title: 15 migrants, driver hurt in rollover crash after high-speed chase
node.description: Two of the injured were in critical condition after the crash in the San Antonio area.

node.title: Video shows "law-abiding" bear looking both ways, using crosswalk
node.description: "Although officers appreciated the law-abiding bear, it was important to get the bear back to a wooded area for safety," police said.

node.title: 11 bodies found after tour boat carrying 26 people sinks in Japan
node.description: The Kazu 1 with two crew was taking 24 passengers on a scenic tour at Shiretoko National Park when it sent a distress call.

node.title: Hundreds of women protest after law student found dead in Mexico
node.description: The young woman was left on the side of a highway late at night, purportedly after a taxi driver tried to fondle her.

node.title: U.N. chief to meet Putin in Moscow to push for Ukraine ceasefire
node.description: Ukraine's leader has questioned the wisdom of Secretary-General Antonio Guterres' decision to meet Putin before coming to Ukraine.

node.title: Family addresses college athlete Sarah Shulze taking her own life at 21
node.description: Sarah Shulze ran on the University of Wisconsin's track and cross country teams. Her family said, "Balancing athletics, academics and the demands of everyday life overwhelmed her in a single, desperate moment."

node.title: World's oldest person, 119-year-old woman, dies in Japan
node.description: Kane Tanaka was born in 1903 in the southwestern Fukuoka region of Japan — the year of the Wright brothers' first flight and when Marie Curie became the first woman to win a Nobel Prize.

node.title: 'My world is destroyed' says father of baby killed in Russian air strike
node.description: Yuriy Glodan had only left his flat and family to go to the shops when he heard the news of the explosion.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 5690 new community cases, 10 deaths
node.description: There have been 10 deaths and 5690 new community cases of Covid-19 in the country in the latest reporting period, the Ministry of Health says.

node.title: Anzac Day in photos: Thousands pay respects
node.description: Thousands have turned out for Anzac Day services and commemorations around the country - here's the day in photos.

node.title: Leaders welcome Emmanuel Macron's re-election
node.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has joined European leaders in warmly congratulating Emmanuel Macron on his re-election as France's president.

node.title: WTA sends warning over Wimbledon ban
node.description: The Women's Tennis Association is warning Wimbledon organisers of "strong reactions" to their decision to ban players from Russia and Belarus from competing in tournaments.

node.title: France's Macron beats Le Pen to win second term
node.description: French President Emmanuel Macron defeated his far-right rival Marine Le Pen on Sunday by a comfortable margin, early projections by pollsters showed, heading off what would have been a political…

node.title: Blinken, Austin, Zelenskyy meet in Ukraine's capital in secret
node.description: Journalists who traveled with the U.S. secretaries of state and defense to Poland were barred from reporting on the trip until it was over.

node.title: Man killed in stabbing incident 'turned his whole life around'
node.description: A 25-year-old man who died in a double stabbing in Invercargill at the weekend had "turned his whole life around for his family".

node.title: Worker dies during coal loading operation at Lyttelton Port
node.description: A person has died during the loading of coal onto a ship at Lyttelton Port this morning.

node.title: First all-private astronaut team aboard space station ready to fly home
node.description: The team has completed a two-week science mission hailed as a milestone in commercial spaceflight.

node.title: Top U.S. diplomats meet with Zelenskyy in secrecy shrouded meeting
node.description: Journalists who traveled with the U.S. secretaries of state and defense to Poland were barred from reporting on the trip until it was over.

node.title: Ukraine to call for heavy arms when top US officials visit Kyiv
node.description: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin are set to visit Kyiv as the Russian invasion enters its third month.

node.title: Nigeria in trauma after Imo refinery deaths - President Buhari
node.description: Nigeria's president has said the country is in "shock and trauma" following the deaths of at least 100 people from an explosion at an illegal oil refinery.

node.title: Commercial crew heads home from space station
node.description: The first commercial crew to visit the space station is targeting splashdown off the coast of Jacksonville.

node.title: 'Paying the price daily' - parent visas delayed again
node.description: Migrant parents who want to join their adult children as residents in New Zealand have longer to wait before a decision is made on restarting a long-shelved immigration programme.

node.title: House shot at in west Auckland, no one injured
node.description: Police are investigating an incident during which a firearm was discharged at a house in Te Atatū from outside the property in the early hours.

node.title: Man dies in water-related incident at Piha
node.description: A man has died after getting into trouble at Piha beach west of Auckland this morning.

node.title: Director Christopher Wray lays out the FBI's major challenges
node.description: In a rare interview, Wray speaks with Scott Pelley about how the bureau is engaging the war in Ukraine while fighting rising violence at home and foreign and domestic terrorism.

node.title: Inside the documents obtained from Osama bin Laden's compound
node.description: During the mission that killed Osama bin Laden, Navy SEALs seized thousands of the al Qaeda leader's personal letters and notes. Sharyn Alfonsi speaks with the woman who's analyzed it all.

node.title: Defence Force marks 40 years keeping peace in Middle East
node.description: The New Zealand Defence Force is today marking 40 years since it began contributing to an international peacekeeping force on the Sinai Peninsula.
